body:
`ctx.configuration.id` / `ctx.configuration.short_id` ?

- I'm not 100% convinced we need both, especially with `short_id` being a prefix of `id` with a known stable algorithm. But no doubt each has their relative benefits.
- Seems like a shame to overload this in cquery's `build_options` API. I guess `ctx.configuration.build_options` could work, then update the `build_options` object with whatever info needed.

> Added bonus of being ConfiguredTarget.getConfigurationKey() versus some other hash, is that a user can debug issues with targets by using that hash directly in cquery

+1. We have a canonical hash to represent configuration keys and should keep that canonical.

My only concern with this is analysis caching. By depending on the ID, a target effectively depends on every single option and thus necessarily has to be reanalyzed whenever it changes. The same holds for all targets that transitively depend on it.

@brentleyjones Could you share a snippet demonstrating how you would use this is in a rule? Maybe we'll be able point out a more limited way for making this information available that's still good enough for your use case.

> I'm not 100% convinced we need both, especially with short_id being a prefix of id with a known stable algorithm. But no doubt each has their relative benefits

If we only add one, it should be `short_id` - otherwise folks will replicate the current "algorithm" used to compute it, which will make it much harder to change if we ever run into collisions.

Here is how it's currently gathered in **rules_xcodeproj**: https://github.com/MobileNativeFoundation/rules_xcodeproj/blob/754ac5d209bedad6fd6a128b8522df934d1140c5/xcodeproj/internal/processed_targets/library_targets.bzl#L53-L55. `configuration` is what would be set to the config ID. We use it both for non-cachable stuff (output group names) but we also write it into artifacts so it's displayed to the user when we need to disambiguate targets.

I understand this will have an impact on caching, but in my use case it's acceptable.

> My only concern with this is analysis caching. By depending on the ID, a target effectively depends on every single option and thus necessarily has to be reanalyzed whenever it changes. The same holds for all targets that transitively depend on it.

What concrete caching impact do you mean? Configured targets have this property already in the absence of flag trimming.

I was thinking of the idea we discussed a while ago where CTs would track the Starlark flags they transitively consume and then be "grafted" onto compatible ConfiguredTargetKeys when the flags change, ignoring differences outside the sets of tracked flags.

This wouldn't work for targets that consume all flags. We could propagate a special value upwards that signals this, so it's not a blocker, just something to keep in mind as potentially detrimental to future optimizations.
